Award.AwardTitle: Convergence Accelerator Phase I(RAISE): Rapid Dissemination of AI Microcredentials through Hands-On Industrial Robotics Education (RD-AIM-HIRE)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF Convergence Accelerator supports team-based, multidisciplinary efforts that address challenges of national importance and show potential for deliverables in the near future.

The broader impact/ potential benefit of this Convergence Accelerator Phase I project is to facilitate convergence of literature and methodologies from sociology, human-computer interaction, microcredentialing, software engineering, and improvement science to improve collaborative development and delivery processes for training robotics technicians who can meet the needs of American manufacturers both today and during the impending transition to an "Industry 4.0" paradigm in which factory floors are transformed into networked cyber-physical systems controlled by specialized artificial intelligence (AI) software. Technicians will remain critical in the installation and maintenance of advanced manufacturing systems, but they must understand such systems in order to troubleshoot them effectively. Good training is both authentic and consistently deliverable. Achieving this requires coordination between curriculum designers, subject matter experts, educational practitioners, and many other stakeholders. The endeavor has been approached alternately as a "product design" problem from the curriculum development perspective, or an "organizational coordination" problem from an organizational policy perspective. Our approach connects these two perspectives in a transdisciplinary effort to produce a technical training apparatus that can keep pace with rapid advancement in fields like machine learning and AI.

This Convergence Accelerator Phase I project takes a design research approach to fusing the organizations-inward and product-outward approaches into a single efficient enterprise. Our project employs design and improvement science methods to answer questions about (i) How to design effective and deliverable machine learning (ML) curriculum for technician trainees with little or no STEM background; and (ii) How to design productive collaborative routines around this objective, given the wide variety of stakeholders. We start with a "shovel-ready" curriculum concept and an experienced production team that uses human-centered design (HCD) techniques to design usable, pedagogically effective activities. In addition to authorial consultation with AI subject matter experts, HCD involves data collection on instructors, learners, and their extended learning contexts including administrative and social aspects. We problematize collaboration patterns of the production team with other stakeholders during this process, identifying improved routines to accelerate the collaborative's joint work. This phase of the project produces knowledge of how to accelerate curriculum design through enhanced collaborative routines, knowledge of how ML/AI can be integrated into technician training, prototype ML/AI curriculum for non-four-year audiences, and direct training impact for pilot participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our team of experts and practitioners from educational, organizational, and technological fields conducted an accelerated design-based research effort to prepare entry-level technicians for work with advanced manufacturing technologies. The program was designed to connect underserved communities to open entry-level technician positions in robotics-based manufacturing across the United States, with an emphasis on preparation for machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) technologies. We focused on the training needs of American small and medium-sized manufacturers (SMMs), who typically lack the resources to investigate advanced technologies and/or to provide internal training to upskill workers to use these technologies.

We collected data through observations, interviews, panels, user testing, and a systematic literature review. These data suggested that the six-week bootcamp training the team initially proposed would not work for several reasons. First, the bootcamp prepared entry-level workers, but small and medium manufacturers did not value ML training at entry level. Since employers didn’t value it, trainees also saw learning ML as a waste of time. Second, employers were uninterested in broad technology pre-training, preferring to invest in specific training after a new equipment purchase.

Thus, our original strategy of developing ML and AI skills in the manufacturing workforce through entry-level training was incompatible with the priorities of both employers and employees and would ultimately not have been viable. This finding is noteworthy, as it refutes the logic of up-front training as a broad means of achieving advanced technological readiness for the US manufacturing workforce.

We subsequently redesigned our training approach to include two parallel programs based on two key insights.

SkillUP. Existing training approaches either regard technology adoption as prerequisite to technology training (new equipment training) or vice versa (customer education). However, since neither adoption nor training is presently widespread among American SMMs, neither prerequisite is met, and neither approach works. Our redesigned training instead treats the two as reciprocal, placing basic knowledge of advanced manufacturing technology in the hands of workers, empowering them to uncover profitable opportunities for technology adoption (on which they subsequently receive focused training). SkillUP kicks off this process with extremely lightweight, hands-on professional development directly to manufacturers’ sites via a mobile workshop, at little to no cost.

BootUP. Incumbent worker upskilling, however, is not enough. Unfilled entry-level positions remain an existential threat to small and medium manufacturers, rendering moot any progress made on technology adoption if left unchecked. BootUP rapidly trains entry-level workers through a streamlined two-week bootcamp, augmented with on-the-ground support from new partners at Goodwill Industries International and the Manufacturing Extension Partnership (MEP) network. Importantly, these partners enable scaling through their national networks. A dedicated smartphone app consolidates access to curriculum and support services in a single location.

Detailed designs of both the BootUP and SkillUP programs were presented toward our Factory Forward Phase II submission, and a series of promotional videos describing both sub-programs can be found at https://www.cmu.edu/roboticsacademy/Research/rd-aim-hire.html. One particularly notable program innovation is the bootcamp design in BootUP, which greatly shortens training while foregrounding technical collaboration, by training members of a team in different technical specialties, then reconvening them for an integrated capstone project.

Prototype lesson materials were also developed for both revised curriculum strands. Significant revisions were made to streamline the publicly available Mechanical, Electrical, Fabrication, and Software Foundations courses, and the Robotics Integration course. New prototype activity modules were created for Additive Manufacturing, Preventative Maintenance, and Machine Vision Quality Control. All modules can be accessed for free at https://www.cmu.edu/roboticsacademy/Research/rd-aim-hire.html.

In support of the curriculum, novel technology was developed to integrate the Unity3D game engine with the MobileNET-based machine vision library, allowing trainees to interactively learn ML model training, by training an image classification algorithm on 3D rendered assets in seconds, entirely in a web browser. A second product was a game-based preventative maintenance lesson module, in which trainees trained and reused ML models to increase the profitability of a virtual factory. This module experimented with the use of role-taking to help workers see the value of ML from a management perspective, and also served as a technical platform to implement a browser-based Unity3D game world with cloud-based computing to train the ML models through “serverless” lambda calls. Source code for reusable products has been released under open source license, and articles detailing their use with examples are published on web blogging platform Medium.  See https://www.cmu.edu/roboticsacademy/Research/rd-aim-hire.html.

In addition, one interim report summarizing insights from stakeholder interviews with Manufacturing Institute member companies was produced; and researchers and developers on the team received training from world experts in human-centered design, team science, and technology entrepreneurship. Finally, the network of complementary partners assembled during Phase I has continued to pursue opportunities to fund work together.
